content.heading: PHASE 1: Identify the Clause Structure
content.subtitle: Independent vs. Dependent—Everything Flows From This

core_principle.title: The Foundation
core_principle.description: Punctuation rules depend on whether you're connecting independent clauses, dependent clauses, or neither. Master this distinction and punctuation becomes predictable.

clause_types.definition: Can stand alone as complete sentence (Subject + Verb + Complete Thought)
clause_types.key_test: Could this be a sentence by itself? If YES → independent

clause_types.definition: Has subject + verb BUT cannot stand alone (starts with subordinating word)
examples: Because renewable energy is growing rapidly
clause_types.subordinating_words: because, although, when, if, since, while, unless, until, after, before, though
clause_types.key_test: Could this be a sentence by itself? If NO → dependent

clause_types.definition: Group of words lacking subject-verb combination
clause_types.key_test: Does this have a subject AND verb? If NO → phrase

strategy_steps.title: Find the Verbs
strategy_steps.description: Locate all finite verbs in the sentence
strategy_steps.example: The team won the game, they celebrated afterwards. → verbs: 'won,' 'celebrated'

strategy_steps.title: Identify the Clauses
strategy_steps.description: Group each verb with its subject
strategy_steps.example: Clause 1: 'The team won the game' | Clause 2: 'they celebrated afterwards'

strategy_steps.title: Test Independence
strategy_steps.example: Both can stand alone → BOTH INDEPENDENT → Need strong punctuation between them

options.example: The experiment succeeded. The team celebrated.
The experiment succeeded; the team had worked for months.
options.note: Semicolons show connection—use when ideas flow together logically

options.example: The experiment succeeded, and the team celebrated.
options.conjunctions: FANBOYS: for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so

punctuation_rules.deadly_error: COMMA ALONE between independent clauses = COMMA SPLICE (automatic wrong answer)

punctuation_rules.rule: Use COMMA after dependent clause when it comes first

examples.correct: Although the test was difficult, most students passed.
Most students passed although the test was difficult.
examples.structure: [Independent] [Dependent] — NO COMMA when dependent comes second

punctuation_rules.rule: Use COMMA after introductory phrase or word
examples: After studying for hours, Maria felt confident.
In the morning, we'll discuss the plan.
punctuation_rules.note: Short intros (2-3 words) sometimes skip comma, but when in doubt, use it

punctuation_rules.rule: Set off with COMMAS (or dashes) on BOTH sides
examples: The scientist, who was determined to succeed, worked tirelessly.
Maria, the team leader, presented the findings.
The experiment, conducted over three years, produced valuable data.
punctuation_rules.test: Can you remove the part between commas and still have complete sentence? If YES → non-essential, needs commas

special_punctuation.rule: Introduces list, explanation, or example AFTER INDEPENDENT CLAUSE
requirements: What follows explains, lists, or exemplifies what came before

examples.correct: The recipe requires three ingredients: flour, eggs, and milk.
examples.why: Complete sentence before colon, list after

examples.incorrect: The ingredients are: flour, eggs, and milk.
examples.why: NOT a complete sentence before colon

two_uses.example: The experiment failed; the data was still valuable.

two_uses.use: Separate items in complex lists (when items contain commas)
two_uses.example: The conference had attendees from Paris, France; London, England; and Berlin, Germany.

elements.reveal: Comma between independent clauses WITHOUT conjunction = automatic error. This is SAT's #1 punctuation trap.

content.heading: PHASE 3: Master Apostrophe Rules
content.subtitle: The 100% Rule: Possession vs. Plural vs. Contraction

core_principle.title: Three Uses, Three Rules
core_principle.description: Apostrophes have exactly three jobs. Learn these and you'll never miss an apostrophe question.

rules.case: Plural noun NOT ending in s

apostrophe_uses.key_test: Ask: Does something belong to this noun? If YES → needs apostrophe

apostrophe_uses.rule: Replaces missing letters when combining two words
apostrophe_uses.key_test: Can you expand this to two words? If YES → contraction needs apostrophe

deadly_errors.example: The dog wagged its tail. (NOT it's)

deadly_errors.when_wrong: Never correct—possessive pronouns don't use apostrophes

apostrophe_uses.note: Simple plurals NEVER use apostrophes: dogs, books, students (NOT dog's, book's, student's unless showing possession)

steps.question: Is it showing possession?
steps.if_yes: Check if it's a possessive pronoun

slides.title: Guided Practice: The Strategy in Action

content.heading: Let's Apply All 3 Phases Together
content.passage: The companys new policy affects all employees however some workers arent sure about it's implementation. The managers explanation was clear: all departments must follow the same procedures and everyone's input is valued during the transition.
content.question: Which choice correctly punctuates the passage?

walkthrough.question: How many independent clauses in sentence 1?
walkthrough.answer: TWO: 'The companys new policy affects all employees' + 'some workers arent sure about it's implementation'
walkthrough.reasoning: Both can stand alone as complete sentences

walkthrough.question: What punctuation is between these independent clauses?
walkthrough.answer: Just 'however' with no punctuation—this is a RUN-ON
walkthrough.reasoning: Independent + Independent needs strong punctuation. 'However' is a transition word, NOT a conjunction. Must be: period/semicolon before 'however,' comma after

walkthrough.question: Find ALL apostrophe errors
walkthrough.answer: Multiple errors: companys, arent, it's, managers, everyone's

walkthrough.question: Is the colon used correctly?
walkthrough.answer: YES—'The manager's explanation was clear' is complete sentence, and colon introduces the explanation
walkthrough.reasoning: Colon requires complete sentence before it ✓

options_analysis.text: The company's new policy affects all employees; however, some workers aren't sure about its implementation. The manager's explanation was clear: all departments must follow the same procedures, and everyone's input is valued during the transition.
options_analysis.analysis:
✓ CORRECT—Fixes all errors:
- company's (possession) ✓
- semicolon before however ✓
- comma after however ✓
- aren't (contraction) ✓
- its (possessive pronoun, no apostrophe) ✓
- manager's (possession) ✓
- colon usage correct ✓
- everyone's (possession) ✓

options_analysis.text: The companys new policy affects all employees, however, some workers aren't sure about it's implementation...
options_analysis.analysis:
✗ Multiple errors:
- Missing apostrophe in 'companys'
- Comma splice (comma before 'however' with independent clauses)
- Wrong 'it's' (should be 'its')
- Missing other apostrophes

options_analysis.text: The company's new policy affects all employees, however some workers aren't sure about it's implementation...
options_analysis.analysis:
✗ Errors:
- Comma splice (comma alone between independent clauses)
- Missing comma after 'however'
- Wrong 'it's' (should be 'its')

options_analysis.text: The companies new policy affects all employees; however some workers arent sure about its implementation...
options_analysis.analysis:
✗ Errors:
- Wrong 'companies' (should be company's—singular possession)
- Missing apostrophe in 'arent'
- Missing comma after 'however'
- Missing other apostrophes

slides.title: Your Turn: Apply the PAUSE Strategy

content.heading: Independent Practice
content.instructions: Use all 3 phases: Identify Clauses → Apply Rules → Check Apostrophes
content.passage: The students final projects were impressive each one demonstrated creativity and technical skill. However some students couldnt complete there work on time, this created problems for the teachers assessment schedule. The departments new policy is simple: late work results in grade reductions but students can request extensions if they're facing genuine difficulties.
content.question: Which choice best corrects all punctuation errors in the passage?
content.strategy_reminder: Phase 1: Count independent clauses. Phase 2: Strong punctuation between them? Phase 3: Check every apostrophe—possession, contraction, or neither?

options: The students' final projects were impressive; each one demonstrated creativity and technical skill. However, some students couldn't complete their work on time, which created problems for the teacher's assessment schedule. The department's new policy is simple: late work results in grade reductions, but students can request extensions if they're facing genuine difficulties.

The student's final projects were impressive, each one demonstrated creativity and technical skill. However some students couldn't complete there work on time; this created problems for the teachers assessment schedule. The departments new policy is simple: late work results in grade reductions but students can request extensions if there facing genuine difficulties.

The students final projects were impressive; each one demonstrated creativity and technical skill. However, some students couldn't complete their work on time, this created problems for the teacher's assessment schedule. The department's new policy is simple; late work results in grade reductions, but students can request extensions if they're facing genuine difficulties.

The students' final projects were impressive each one demonstrated creativity and technical skill. However, some students couldnt complete their work on time, this created problems for the teachers' assessment schedule. The departments new policy is simple: late work results in grade reductions but students can request extensions if they're facing genuine difficulties.
content.explanation:
Let's apply the 3 phases:

PHASE 1: Sentence 1 has TWO independent clauses ('projects were impressive' + 'each one demonstrated')

PHASE 2: Need strong punctuation between independent clauses

PHASE 3: Apostrophe analysis:
- 'students' final projects' = plural possession (projects belong to multiple students) → students'
- 'couldn't' = contraction (could not) → couldn't
- 'there' vs 'their' = possessive needed → their
- 'teacher's assessment' = singular possession → teacher's
- 'department's policy' = singular possession → department's
- 'they're' = contraction (they are) → they're

A: ✓ CORRECT—All errors fixed: students' (plural possession), semicolon between independent clauses, couldn't, their, teacher's, department's, comma before 'but', they're

B: Multiple errors—'student's' wrong (should be plural), comma splice, wrong 'there', missing apostrophes

C: Wrong 'there' (should be 'their'), comma splice with 'this created'

D: No punctuation between independent clauses (run-on), missing 'couldn't' apostrophe

content.heading: Master These Patterns—Perfect Punctuation Every Time

rows: Period, semicolon, OR comma+conjunction (NEVER comma alone)
X. Y  /  X; Y  /  X, and Y
Comma after dependent if it comes first (no comma if second)
Although X, Y  /  Y although X
However, X  /  In the morning, X
X requires three things: A, B, C

content.expert_insight: The comma splice (comma alone between independent clauses) is SAT's most common punctuation trap. When you see 'X, however Y' or 'X, this Y'—it's almost always wrong.

content.heading: Punctuation Mastery
key_points: Phase 1: Identify clause structure—independent vs. dependent determines punctuation
Phase 2: Independent + Independent needs STRONG punctuation (never comma alone)
Phase 3: Apostrophes have THREE uses—possession (nouns only), contractions, and possessive pronouns (NO apostrophe)
The 100% Rule: 'However' and 'therefore' are NOT conjunctions—need semicolon or period before them
content.strategy_reminder: Remember PAUSE: Parse clauses, Apply punctuation rules, Understand apostrophe rules, Select correct option, Eliminate errors
content.expert_insight: On the SAT, possessive pronouns (its, whose, theirs) NEVER have apostrophes. Contractions (it's, who's, they're) ALWAYS do.

strategy_card.title: The PAUSE Strategy Quick Reference

steps: Find all verbs and identify clauses
Test: Can each clause stand alone?
Independent + Independent: period, semicolon, or comma+conjunction
Non-essential info: commas on both sides
Possessive pronoun: NO apostrophe (its, whose, theirs)

strategy_card.the_100_rule: Comma alone between independent clauses = automatic error. Possessive pronouns (its, whose, theirs) NEVER have apostrophes.

common_mistakes: Comma splice between independent clauses (especially with 'however,' 'therefore,' 'this')

punctuation_quick_reference.Comma Splice: Independent, independent → WRONG | Use: period, semicolon, or comma+conjunction
punctuation_quick_reference.Apostrophe Test: Contraction? → Use apostrophe | Pronoun possession? → NO apostrophe | Noun possession? → Use apostrophe
punctuation_quick_reference.Colon Rule: Must follow complete sentence, introduces list/explanation
punctuation_quick_reference.However/Therefore: Need semicolon or period BEFORE these words when joining independent clauses
